prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The line FWHM in MWC 480 is ~6 km/s (Oberg et al. 2015). We ask for a spectral resolution of 0.1 km/s to resolve as much velocity structure as possible in the brightest lines. For the target lines HC15N and C15N, which are much weaker, we will smooth the spectra to 2 km/s to achieve the requested sensitivity.

We ask for a spectral resolution of 0.1 km/s to resolve as much velocity structure as possible in the brightest lines. In order to increase the scientific value and maximize the chance of serendipitous discoveries, we set additional spectral windows on other molecules of known or potential value: CO 3-2, SO2 5(5,1)-6(4,2), CS 7-6, CH3OH 5(-2,4)-4(1,3), 34SO 2(3)-2(1), H2-13CO 5(1,5)-4(1,4), and HCN 4-3. One full baseband is dedicated to the continuum.

In ALMA Cycle 2, H13CN and HC15N 3-2 were detected in MWC 480 in a 0.6" beam (Oberg et al. 2015; Oberg priv. comm.). We request the same resolution (0.6") for our observations of H13CN and HC15N 4-3 and CN and C15N 3-2.
The outer radius of MWC 480 is ~150 AU (Guilloteau et al. 2011) at a distance of 140 pc, so the largest angular scale is 2*150/140 = 2.1". This is significantly smaller than the largest scales that can be recovered.

Oberg et al. (2015) detected a peak flux in MWC 480 of 25 mJy in a 0.6" beam for H13CN 3-2. They used the disk model of Guilloteau et al. (2011) to derive the best-fit abundance structure. We ran their model and abundance structure through the radiative transfer code LIME (Brinch & Hogerheijde 2010) to estimate the flux for H13CN 4-3, which ends up a factor 2.2 stronger than the 3-2 line. Based on ISM isotope ratios (which are a conservative estimate, based on the 15N enrichment seen in our chemical models), HC15N would be a factor 6.4 less abundant than H13CN. The expected peak flux for HC15N 4-3 is then 25 x 2.2 / 6.4 = 8.6 mJy. We therefore request a sensitivity of 1.7 mJy in 2 km/s channels (the coarsest needed to resolve the linewidth of 4-6 km/s) to get at least a 5sigma detection.

The line FWHM in MWC 480 is ~6 km/s (Oberg et al. 2015). We ask for a spectral resolution of 0.1 km/s to resolve as much velocity structure as possible in the brightest lines. For the target lines HC15N and C15N, which are much weaker, we will smooth the spectra to 2 km/s to achieve the requested sensitivity.

In ALMA Cycle 2, H13CN and HC15N 3-2 were detected in MWC 480 in a 0.6" beam (Oberg et al. 2015; Oberg priv. comm.). We request the same resolution (0.6") for our observations of H13CN and HC15N 4-3 and CN and C15N 3-2.
The outer radius of MWC 480 is ~150 AU (Guilloteau et al. 2011) at a distance of 140 pc, so the largest angular scale is 2*150/140 = 2.1". This is significantly smaller than the largest scales that can be recovered.

Using the JCMT (15" beam), Thi et al. (2004) observed an integrated intensity in MWC 480 for the brightest hyperfine component of CN 3-2 of 0.29 K km/s, with a peak intensity of 0.08 K. They inferred a CN abundance of 1.4e-10. Using the disk model for MWC 280 from Guilloteau et al. (2011) and a constant CN abundance of 1.4e-10, the radiative transfer code LIME (Brinch & Hogerheijde 2010) recovers the JCMT detection within 30%. For C15N, we conservatively scale the abundance of CN down by the ISM 14N/15N ratio of 450. (Because of 15N fractionation, our models actually predict a C15N abundance of at least a factor of 2 higher.) For a 0.6" beam, LIME then predicts a peak flux of 7.1 mJy. To ensure at least a 5sigma detection, we request a sensitivity of 1.4 mJy in 2 km/s channels (the coarsest needed to resolve the linewidth of 4-6 km/s).

We ask for a spectral resolution of 0.1 km/s to resolve as much velocity structure as possible in the brightest lines. In order to increase the scientific value and maximize the chance of serendipitous discoveries, we set additional spectral windows on other molecules of known or potential value: 13CO 3-2 and C18O 3-2. One full baseband is dedicated to the continuum.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: H13CN and HC15N in TW Hya

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The line FWHM in TW Hya is ~0.5 km/s (Kastner et al. 2014), so we require a high spectral resolution of 0.1 km/s to resolve the lines. If needed, we will smooth the weaker HC15N spectra to 0.2 km/s to achieve the requested sensitivity.

We ask for a spectral resolution of 0.1 km/s to resolve the narrow lines in TW Hya. In order to increase the scientific value and maximize the chance of serendipitous discoveries, we set additional spectral windows on other molecules of known or potential value: CO 3-2, SO2 5(5,1)-6(4,2), CS 7-6, CH3OH 5(-2,4)-4(1,3), 34SO 2(3)-2(1), H2-13CO 5(1,5)-4(1,4), and HCN 4-3. One full baseband is dedicated to the continuum.

Our chemical models show that the bulk of nitrogen isotope fractionation in TW Hya occurs at radii of >20 AU. We request a resolution of 0.7", equivalent to 40 AU diameter or 20 AU radius. The outer radius of TW Hya is ~200 AU (Andrews et al. 2012), significantly smaller than the largest scales that can be recovered.

HC15N J=4-3 was detected in the ALMA Science Verification campaign with a peak flux of 150 mJy in a 1.8"x1.6" beam. For our 0.7" beam, assuming uniform emission, the peak flux scales down to 25 mJy. We request a sensitivity of 5 mJy/beam in 0.2 km/s channels (see correlator setup) to ensure a 5sigma detection of HC15N.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: H13CN and HC15N in DM Tau

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The line FWHM in DM Tau is ~0.7 km/s (Guilloteau et al. 2006). We ask for a spectral resolution of 0.1 km/s to resolve as much velocity structure as possible in the brightest lines. For the target lines HC15N and C15N, which are much weaker, we will smooth the spectra to 0.2 km/s to achieve the requested sensitivity.

We ask for a spectral resolution of 0.1 km/s to resolve as much velocity structure as possible in the brightest lines. In order to increase the scientific value and maximize the chance of serendipitous discoveries, we set additional spectral windows on other molecules of known or potential value: CO 3-2, SO2 5(5,1)-6(4,2), CS 7-6, CH3OH 5(-2,4)-4(1,3), 34SO 2(3)-2(1), H2-13CO 5(1,5)-4(1,4), and HCN 4-3. One full baseband is dedicated to the continuum.

Our chemical models show that the bulk of nitrogen isotope fractionation in DM Tau occurs at radii of >70 AU. We request a resolution of 1.0", equivalent to 140 AU diameter or 70 AU radius. The outer radius of DM Tau is 800 AU (Teague et al. 2015), so the total source size is 11.4". This is larger than the largest recoverable scale of ~9". However, our models only show detectable HC15N and C15N emission out to at most 6", so that is the relevant largest scale for these observations.

Teague et al. (2015) constructed a parameterized disk model for DM Tau based on PdBI data. Dutrey et al. (1997) targeted several molecular lines in DM Tau with the IRAM 30m telescope (11" beam), including HCN 1-0 (detected at 0.38 Jy km/s) and 3-2 (upper limit of 1.9 Jy km/s). We ran the disk model of Teague et al. through the radiative transfer program LIME (Brinch & Hogerheijde 2010), adjusting a constant HCN abundance until we recovered the flux measured by Dutrey et al.
For a conservative HC15N abundance of 1/450 that of HCN, LIME predicts an integrated flux for HC15N 4-3 of 21 mJy km/s in a 1.0" beam. For a linewidth of 0.7 km/s, the expected peak flux is 28 mJy. We request a sensitivity of 5.6 mJy in 0.3 km/s channels to ensure at least a 5sigma detection.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CN and C15N in DM Tau

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The line FWHM in DM Tau is ~0.7 km/s (Guilloteau et al. 2006). We ask for a spectral resolution of 0.1 km/s to resolve as much velocity structure as possible in the brightest lines. For the target lines HC15N and C15N, which are much weaker, we will smooth the spectra to 0.2 km/s to achieve the requested sensitivity.

Our chemical models show that the bulk of nitrogen isotope fractionation in DM Tau occurs at radii of >70 AU. We request a resolution of 1.0", equivalent to 140 AU diameter or 70 AU radius. The outer radius of DM Tau is 800 AU (Teague et al. 2015), so the total source size is 11.4". This is larger than the largest recoverable scale of ~9". However, our models only show detectable HC15N and C15N emission out to at most 6", so that is the relevant largest scale for these observations.

Teague et al. (2015) constructed a parameterized disk model for DM Tau based on PdBI data. Dutrey et al. (1997) targeted several molecular lines in DM Tau with the IRAM 30m telescope (11" beam), including CN 2-1 (detected at 8.7 Jy km/s). We ran the disk model of Teague et al. through the radiative transfer program LIME (Brinch & Hogerheijde 2010), adjusting a constant CN abundance until we recovered the flux measured by Dutrey et al.
For a conservative C15N abundance of 1/450 that of CN, LIME predicts an integrated flux for the strongest C15N 3-2 hyperfine line of 20 mJy km/s in a 1.0" beam. For a linewidth of 0.7 km/s, the expected peak flux is 26 mJy. We request a sensitivity of 5.2 mJy in 0.3 km/s channels to ensure at least a 5sigma detection.

We ask for a spectral resolution of 0.1 km/s to resolve as much velocity structure as possible in the brightest lines. In order to increase the scientific value and maximize the chance of serendipitous discoveries, we set additional spectral windows on other molecules of known or potential value: 13CO 3-2 and C18O 3-2. One full baseband is dedicated to the continuum.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: H13CN and HC15N in AB Aur

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The line FWHM in AB Aur is ~4 km/s (Pacheco-Vazquez et al.\ 2015). We ask for a spectral resolution of 0.1 km/s to resolve as much velocity structure as possible in the brightest lines. For the target lines HC15N and C15N, which are much weaker, we will smooth the spectra to 1.5 km/s to achieve the requested sensitivity.

We ask for a spectral resolution of 0.1 km/s to resolve as much velocity structure as possible in the brightest lines. In order to increase the scientific value and maximize the chance of serendipitous discoveries, we set additional spectral windows on other molecules of known or potential value: CO 3-2, SO2 5(5,1)-6(4,2), CS 7-6, CH3OH 5(-2,4)-4(1,3), 34SO 2(3)-2(1), H2-13CO 5(1,5)-4(1,4), and HCN 4-3. One full baseband is dedicated to the continuum.

Our chemical models show that the bulk of nitrogen isotope fractionation occurs at radii 110 AU in AB Aur (outside the inner hole; Pacheco-Vazquez et al. 2015). We request a resolution of 1.5", equivalent to 220 AU diameter or 110 AU radius. The outer radius of AB Aur is ~550 AU (Pacheco-Vazquez et al. 2015), slightly smaller than the largest scales that can be recovered.

Based on our chemical models and on models and observations from the literature (Pacheco-Vazquez et al. 2015), we ran radiative transfer calculations with LIME (Brinch & Hogerheijde 2010) to estimate line intensities HC15N and C15N in AB Aur. For a spatial resolution of 1.5" (220 AU diameter or 110 AU radius), our LIME models predict line fluxes of ~40 mJy km/s each for HC15N 4-3 and C15N 3-2 if we choose a conservative 14N/15N ratio of 450 in both molecules. For the linewidth in AB Aur, the expected peak intensity is 12 mJy. We request a sensitivity of 2.4 mJy/beam in 1.5 km/s channels (see correlator setup) to ensure 5sigma detections of HC15N and C15N.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CN and C15N in AB Aur

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We ask for a spectral resolution of 0.1 km/s to resolve as much velocity structure as possible in the brightest lines. In order to increase the scientific value and maximize the chance of serendipitous discoveries, we set additional spectral windows on other molecules of known or potential value: 13CO 3-2 and C18O 3-2. One full baseband is dedicated to the continuum.

Our chemical models show that the bulk of nitrogen isotope fractionation occurs at radii 110 AU in AB Aur (outside the inner hole; Pacheco-Vazquez et al. 2015). We request a resolution of 1.5", equivalent to 220 AU diameter or 110 AU radius. The outer radius of AB Aur is ~550 AU (Pacheco-Vazquez et al. 2015), slightly smaller than the largest scales that can be recovered.

Based on our chemical models and on models and observations from the literature (Pacheco-Vazquez et al. 2015), we ran radiative transfer calculations with LIME (Brinch & Hogerheijde 2010) to estimate line intensities HC15N and C15N in AB Aur. For a spatial resolution of 1.5" (220 AU diameter or 110 AU radius), our LIME models predict line fluxes of ~40 mJy km/s each for HC15N 4-3 and C15N 3-2 if we choose a conservative 14N/15N ratio of 450 in both molecules. For the linewidth in AB Aur, the expected peak intensity is 12 mJy. We request a sensitivity of 2.4 mJy/beam in 1.5 km/s channels (see correlator setup) to ensure 5sigma detections of HC15N and C15N.

We ask for a spectral resolution of 0.1 km/s to resolve as much velocity structure as possible in the brightest lines. In order to increase the scientific value and maximize the chance of serendipitous discoveries, we set additional spectral windows on other molecules of known or potential value: 13CO 3-2 and C18O 3-2. One full baseband is dedicated to the continuum.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
Nitrogen, the most abundant element in Earth's atmosphere, comes in two stable isotopes: 14N and the rarer 15N. The 15N/14N ratio on Earth is 60% higher than in the Sun. Even stronger 15N enhancements are seen in comets, meteorites, and interplanetary dust particles. What is the origin of these different ratios in the solar system?
In star-forming environments, 15N can be enhanced through cold gas chemistry or isotope-selective photodissociation. Our astrochemical model with full N isotope chemistry shows fractionation on 40 AU and larger scales for a representative range of T Tauri and Herbig disk parameters. We propose to measure 15N/14N ratios in four protoplanetary disks through spatially resolved observations of H13CN, HC15N, CN, and C15N. The host stars of these disks span three orders of magnitude in UV luminosities; the disks around the more luminous stars are also warmer. We can thus easily test which of the two possible isotope fractionation mechanisms is dominant.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Astronomy Department, Michigan at Ann Arbor, University of
